div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1800. Editor and Manager - - R SIELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIPR.
MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1907.
THE SOCIALIST CONGRESS.
Nervous people who see before them an era ht, in which Socialism, and, by consequence, a

grinding and remorseless tyranny, will be supreme, may take some comfort from the proceedings at the Socialist Congress at Stutt: gart. Presumably, the delegates there assembled know something of what Socialism means, or is intended to mean, but it must strike the most casual observer that the moment anyone of them attempts to define any portion of the theory, or to suggest how it should be applied in practice, the rest fall upon him as though he were a hare in a kennel of beagles. Upon such an elementary point as the question whether the perfect Socialist ought to possess any patriotism we have been favoured by Herr Bebel and M. Hervé with a spectacle which certainly proves that some human passions have not been eliminated from their breasts. Upon the question of the Colonial policy of the future, the entire assemblage appears to have been reduced to inarticulate howls, says the "Globe" and so great was the friction engen
dered that the very translators lose themselves and the amendment of the French
delegates in the amazing confusion. This is no d new thing. It has been characteristic of

every Socialist Congress since the Socialist Congresses began, and there is not the smallest reason to suppose that it will not continue as long as they do. Something is, perhaps, to be set down to the undoubted fact that the average Socialist is an unbalanced and excitable person, but that does not fully account for the phenomenon. The plain fact is that the moment an attempt is made by sincere people--and most of the delegates are as sincere as they are wrong headed-to apply the theory of Socialism to practical lite its defects become so apparent that its defenders are at their wit's end to save it. Each clearly perceived the fatal defect in the plans of the others, and is consequently vociferous for his own equally futile panarea. Socialism may be, and is, a serious danger, because of what it threatens to destroy, but it can never be set up as a constructive policy in any civilised country until its adherents can agree among themselves. That, so far, they have shown themselves utterly unable to do.

div.head: LOCAL, AND GENERAL.
div.p: More Shoe Dinner.

On Saturday the jockeys of the Alexandria Sporting Club and their friends held a dinner at the Abbey hotel, which proved a most enjoyable and sociable meeting. We are, however, compelled to hold over our account thereof until to-morrow as the large amount of copy to hand more than exhausts the space at our disposal. Lost City Found

. Am Egyptian sun temple and a city that has been lost for 3,300 years have been located by Prof. James H. Breasted of the University of Chicago. It is the temple of Sesebi founded by Amenhotep IV. The city is situated in the heart of the almost inaccessible district of Nubia, near the foot of the third cataract on the Nile Earth Dentistry
The art of dentistry was practiced among the Egyptians and Etruscans, and there
the treatment W e
introduced into America by John Grepuwood, who established himself in New York in 1788. In 1790 and again in 1795 he carved in ivory an entire set of teeth for General Washington. Shooting Apollent.

Yesterday morning about 5 o'clock, a shooting accident took place at Ghémileh. A young European man was shooting quail fired without taking precaution, with the rent that Mr. Edward Vitali an official of the Port Said police, who was in front of him received all the charge in his thigh. M Vitali was immediately transported to the Egyptian hospital, and the imprudent author of the accident placed under arrest to await, establishment of responsibility. The wound is serious and may possibly necessitate amputation. Another Tramway Agoldent

What might have been a nasty accident occurred this morning about 8.45, at the tramway crossing between the Sporting Club and Camp de Caesar station. A tram, proceeding towns the eity, came into contact with a two-horse arabesk which was endeavouring to cross the line. The driver managed to clear his horses but in so doing the arabia became wedged in between the car and the Tramway Company's kiosk and there was an ominous rending and splitting of wood, the arabah sustaining considerable damage before the car was brought to a standstill. The near hind of one of the horses was twisted up in some of the wreckage and the animal was extricated with difficulty, to all apparel Shops fortunately, not much the worse. A Woman. Anger

A woman of Russian nationality, paid a visit yesterday to the house of one of her friends in the Rue Telephone, Cairo, where she was cordially welcomed. During the course of their conversation someone knocked at the door, and three young men, friends of the mistress of the house, entered. Middle. As gave visible signs of her annoyance at this interference with her visit, and soon engaged in bitter words with one of the young men, a Frenchman in the employ of the Government. All at once Mlle. A. livid with anger seized a carafe full of water and inflicted a terrible blow on the face of her companion. The friends of the victim fetched a carringe and took him to the caracol, followed by a large crowd. The doctor pronounced the wound serious enough to necessitate a months treatment in hospital. The proces-verbal was communicated to the Consulate and the woman was arrested. Brendful Fire Dane.

Mt. C French engineer living with his with his wife and two children in the Copt Market, Cairo, on Friday evening went to the French hospital in the company with his wife, leaving the two children, both young, alone in the house. One of them slept on the bed while the other played at its foot. No one knows exactly what occurred, but the little girl was heard to give 'vent to heart rending cries and ran down the stairs drying out that there was a fire in the house. A cab man was the first to receive the news, and going up to the room opened the door. A horrible right met his eyes, surrounded by flames, the boy, a child of 11 years, we suffering frightful agonies. The cabman cours geously did what he could by tearing off the burning clothes and rolling the unfortunate child on the mattress. But it was too late

Life was almost extinct, and he was transported to the hospital, where he died yesterday morning. The cabman has had to renounce his work for the time being, owing to terrible burns. The French Consulate opened an in "quest in conjunction with the police and they came to the conclusion that an overturned lamp wm the cause of the accident.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: KAARTOUM GIRL'S SCHOOLS.

CONCLUDED. On the 22nd inst. Mr. John Robertson, asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether he is yet in a position to give the House any information as to schools for girls at Khartoum, appropriation of land there by the Soudan Government, and the possible
application of Wakf property to purposes of education.
Secretary Sir Edward Grey.-- With regard y to the first Question.
The facts were stated in Lord Cromer's last annual Report. They are as follows.

A petition for the establishment of a Government school for girls was received by the Governor General of the Soudan in October last. The matter was fully considered and it was decided in March last that a girls' school Ishonla bed , sufficient funds having
or the purpose. A beginning de with the erection of a
the petitioners were in nose refer the missionary school authorities.
as explained by Lord Cromer, snch Moslem girls as attend missionary schools in Khartoum receive seenlar education only unless at the express wish of their parents or guardians
With regard to the second Question.
The Soudan Government expropriated for public purposes an area of 1,202 feddans of land at the Blue and White Niles. The land
was expropriated under the Land Acquisition e Ordinance, 1903, a copy of which is enclosed.
The prices were fixed by a Commission of three at members, consisting of the sub-Governor and
two official members, and were based on the
prices given at the private sales which had it been affected from time to time of various parts of the land.
The whole of the land expropriated, except a narrow bank on the Blue Nile, consists of a low-lying flat which is flooded at times of high Nile. The bank on the Blue Nile is being
rapidly washed away. The expropriation was made with a view to building a protective e masonry embankment along the Blue Nile to b protect the bank, and of construction works to

reclaim the remainder. The scheme is intimately connected with proposals for connecting Khartoum and Omdurman with a railway and a bridge, and with the eventual erection of quays along the White Nile.
With regard to the second part of this Question, the Egyptian Government have on
two or three occasions expropriated land 'at e Khartoum North (Halfaya) No association of el the name of the "Model Farming Association,"
or any similar name, is known. In 1905 a piece of uncultivated land was expropriated for a Government experimental farm, and the price paid to expropriate private rights over part
of such land was at the rate of LE, 2 a feddan, it but the average price was considerably higher.
No part of this land has been sold. With regard to the third Question.

The Egyptian Government have not confiscated any Wakf property. They have certain Wakf lands in their hands which are at present mainly unproductive, but some of which have a considerable value as building land. The
proceeds are applicable for purposes recognised as charitable by Mohammedan Law, such as
the upkeep of mosques, the payment of
mosque officials, education (especially relief regions edition), alms, etc.
It would not be in accordance with the d wishes of the inhabitants of Egypt so restrict ne the application of Wakf property to education.
additional purposes. COMPANY -PROMOTION RESTRICTIONS

In the House of Commons on Monday last, Mr. Rees asked the Secretary of State for is Foreign Affairs whether Lord Cromer prescribed certain restrictions upon company promo to tion in Egypt, with a view to the protection of b) the investing public ; and, if the answer be in
the affirmative, whether he would inform the
House what such restrictions were. Fol Mr. Runciman, who replied, said his right e hon. friend could only refer the hon.
member to the heading "Mining Concession" ngin Lord Cromer's Report for 1903, page 29.

div.head: SHOUBRA ENGLISH SCHOOL. The Shoubra English School closed on the 26th of June, after a very satisfactory and happy year's work, in the course of which the
div.p: pupils increased from 17 to 49. Good progress He was made both in English and French, the
latter, throughout the school, being under the
able tuition of Mme Léchant y some difficulties occurred in the way of be providing accommodation for the school, says le "Au SaintsChurch Magazine" but these were
overcome, and may be looked upon as blessings
in disguise, inasmuch as they result in hasten ding the building of our own school house. This
will be opened at the beginning of the new school year, when we hope to warm the class rooms with a good tes and games for our children.
Great improvements are hoped for in the coming year, when many new books and maps will be brought out from England...
Alf being well, the annual Prize Giving will he be held in December. Mrs. Foote's prizes of m. 258. and. 158. for general progress, have been
won by George Aitken and Robert McPhee.

Mr. and Mrs. Burns leave Church House on 8ptember 2nd. Their address in future will We - The Dean's Building, Sharia Guesiret Badrane. To find the house go down the Sharia Guesiret Badrone from the Sharia Shoubra, and take the turning between the houses numbered 22 and 24. The Dean's Building is on the left, 200 yards from the Guesiret. Badrane.

div.head: SULTAN'S ACCESSION FETES.
div.p: Most of the buildings of Alexandria flew the Ottoman flag yesterday in celebration of the accession of Sultan Abdul Hamid to the throne of Turkey and at night several of them were illuminated, the illuminations of the Ottoman bank being especially attractive. In the evening, a banquet was given at Ras el-Tin palace by the Regent, Fakhry Pasha, which was attended by the notables of Alexandria. The dinner was followed by a display of fireworks.

div.head: THE DEAN'S BUILDING
div.p: This building, which at present consita of school premises and two small flats, one for the head mistress and the oth for the assistant chaplain, is now completed. On the first floor there are three school-rooms, of which one, measuring 40ft. by 25, is designed to be also used on Sundays, in the afternoon for Sunday School, and later for an Evening Service. There are, besides the school-rooms, library for the children (to be used also as a common room for the teachers) and an office for the head mistress. The sanitary accommodation, provided in buildings quite separate from the school, is arranged on the most approved system. The school is capable of accomodating one hundred children, which is just double the number of the highest attendance during the past school year. The head mistress is due in Cairo about the 25th of September, and she is bringing from England a fresh supply of maps, books, ete. 1. The height of the room on the ground floor slis 4 metres; the school entrance is from the
South, although there are three other exits. T, entrance to the flats is on the north side, by means of a staircase outside the building. The - whole presents a very pleasing appearance, and
I promises to be exceedingly convenient in every way. At the entrance of the school front in marble tablet has been let into the wall bearing the following inscription :
The Dean's BUILDING.

div.head: IN MEMORY OF CHARLES HENRY BUTCHER, D.D.
div.p: Ye are' God'Building.-1 Cor. III., 9. Reminding us of him to whose effort, in the first instance, the school owes its existence.
The total cost of the land and building has been L.E. 3,661.340.

div.head: MERCHANT SHIP ASHORE The SS. "Olive Moor" belonging to Messrs W. Ranciman &
div.p: Son, London, and bound for Alexandria with a general cargo went ashore last evening about 8 o'clock, when trying to make of Alexandria. She is badly ashore on the rocks
about 4 miles 8.W. of Agami. The Coast Guard steamer "Abdel Moneim" returning to Alex
andria sighted the steamer at daylight and n has been attempting to tow her off, but up to is one o'clock she was unsuccessful.
The steamer is making water in No. 1 hold, but after she is dry. We understand the Ports are and Lights túg will leave this afternoon to
render further assistance and that labourers ne are being despatched to lighten the cargo for
ward. The sen is very unfavourable at present
and, unless immediate assistance is rendered, all there will be very little chance of saving the steemer.

div.head: TR, MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1907. NOTES FROM CYPRUS EGYPTIAN VISITORS
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.)
NG

Larnaca, August 29. A decided change of weather took place last week over the whole Island, and an unwanted touch of freshness in the air made itself felt even in the plains, In the higher localities the fall in the temperature was more marked and was almost extreme. Visitors returning from Troodos complained that for some days the cold was excessive two nights the thermometer having fallen to 36° and 30 Fahrenheit respectively. Warmer weather has now returned, but tempered with an unusual lightness and buoyancy in the air, which is as welcome as it is unexpected | peeted in the month of Angast. There is

belief current among the Cypriots that all change to colder conditions takes place from the 15th August, but this rule is more honoured in the breach than in the observance As both August and September are frequently among the hottest and most trying months of the year.

A good number of visitors from Egypt and elsewhere have passed through Limassol during the last few weeks on their way to Troodos. Among them may be mentioned Capt. and Mrs. Swift ; Lieut. Grogan, R. N. and Mrs. Grogan; Borton Bey (Postmaster-General of Egypt) and Mrs. Borton; Mr. Adams; Mr. W. V. Vogell, of Beyrouth; Revd. and Mrs. Thomas, of Cairo, and Major and Mrs. Wilding.

Mr. Laurence King-Harman, eldest son of the High Commissioner, left last mail for England, on the termination of his summer vacation. Mr. J.A.S. Buoknill, King's Advocate, crossed over to Egypt by the same boat in order to meet his wife and bring her to Cyprus.

Mr. Clarence Wodehouse, who for twelve years has been Commissioner of Paphos is about to be transferred, as Commissioner, to Larnaca, in succession to Mr. C. D. Cobham, C.M.G. retired. Mr. Wodehouse has done much valuable work in the Paphos District, where he has identified himself in an exceptional manner with the interests of the people, and has long been regarded by them as a "guide, philosopher and friend." The personal equation counts for much in the administration of a district, and the departure of Mr. Wodehouse and his family cannot fail to be regarded by the large majority of the Paphitis in the light of a personal loss.

The seaward view from our "Marina' has been animated this week. Besides the presence of tour, and occasionally five, steamers e the roadstead has been harbouring a large n number of sailing craft, which has been ang
mented by a small flotilla of sponge fishing
boats from the Greek Islands, which have been n fishing off the Egy tian coast and came over
here for quarantine purposes. 'Blessed are the
uses of adversity! The quarantine dues are o quite a considerable item. These spongers e report having discovered a rich bed of sponges
which they have been working. Some of our

Cyprus sponge boats were also here for a few days a week or so ago. El The erection of the new block of houses d along the front, between the Royal Hotel or and the Pier, is steadily continuing, and 'get along we may see a hotel, and a café restaurant à l'Européenne, in full swing of business at
this prominent and popular corner. The building of the new and imposing premises of the
Imperial Ottoman Bank, adjoining the English Club, is progressing apace.

Large quantities of grain are at present being e shipped from this port. y There have been several forest fires of late e in different parts of the Island. They seem be da chronicevil, and a not inconsiderable amount
of damage is done annually and may be doubt aless attributed as much to the carelessness as & to the malice of the villagers.
The annual report of the Government Analyst on the working of the Food and Drugs Law, during the half-year ended 30th June last is officially published.
The total number of samples received from the different districts was 828, of which 489 were found pare and 84 were found adulterated.

The Government Analyst states: "I have examined a number of tins of food and have found several of them to be unfit for consumption. This food has been tinned years aggregate and should not have been exposed for
sale. The examination of tinned food is having steamy careful attention.
"The number of examples received has greatly increased during the last six months, but I am glad to report that the percentage of pure samples has increased considerably in amused."
The total number of samples of food and Drugs analysed from all sources during the period under report was.
247 Adulterated
Total 835
Pure
1 A comparison with previous figures would lead to the belief that this useful law must be
having a beneficial effect upon the health of the people.
A successful concert was given on 27th
instant by the officers of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers on Mount. Troodos. It was held in the
mens' Recreation Room, and was filled with le an enthusiastic audience who had accepted
the invitation of the Colonel and officers of le the Regiment. Much musical talent was disthe played and the performance was eminently - satisfactory and appears to have given much
pleasure to all concerned..

div.head: LITERARY TREASURE IN ANCIENT EGYPT
div.p: (Continued.) It was not however only beneath a statue that ancient writings were placed for preservation, but also in the foundation walls of sacred buildings, for a note added to another version of the 64th chapter of the "Book of the Dead” than the more common recension says of it, "This chapter was found in the foundations of Amihanna by the overseer of the men who built a wall in the time of King Usasphais, its figures are mysterious, nobody has seen them nor looked at them." This rubrie bears every aspect of truth; the discovery is attributed not to any important personage but merely to an overseer, doubtless superintending some additions or repairs to the temple. Strange to say, however, the lost chapter was found under a king of what has always, up to the present, been considered the first dynasty. Yet this chapter, which has been said is shorter than its commoner duplicate which is called the chapter of "going out of the day," is entitled the "chapter of knowing the chapters of going out of the day in one chapter." It is therefore a condensation in predynastic times of several chapters of the same objective import, which must have been selected from an earlier edition, or collection, forming the "Book of the Dead' than any we have ever known.

The longer and more common chapter is probably one of these primitive ones which were supposed in their intrinsic essence to have been contained in the short version buried in the foundation wall. Such seribal scholia attached to these papyri, or documents, perhaps upon leather or stone, however lead to important inferences. Was this pre-Nilotie dynasty "Book for the Dead" composed in Egypt at all t or was it produced by the so called "followers of Horus," who are supposed to have been invaders of the country, coming from Nobis or Abyssinia and bringing with them a western Asiatie culture ? If it was composed in Egypt and that so long before the first dynasty that some of its chapters were lost and forgotten, then the predynastic period must have been lengthy indeed. More over this missing chapter, it has been pointed out when it was well known and deposited in the wall was a shorter recension of several other chapters, inferring a still further antiquity for them. Some may decline to accept the state. ment of the rubrie that the missing chapter was found under Usafis, but the statement is always found with the short chapter, and a papyrus as old as the 11th dynasty makes the assertion. There is no reason to doubt that had we copies of the "Book of the Dead" containing this version of the chapter earlier than those of the 11th dynasty the usual rubio as to its discovery after having been long lost would also be found in thein. Also Usaphais, according to Egyptian tradition, had something specially to do with the composition of the "Book for the Dead" and it would be reasonable to suppose that the recovery of this chapter during his reign was the incentive inducing him to search for other missing texts and have the work re edited.

Finally the name of the edifice where it was found is of great antiquity; Amihannu "The god inhabiting Hunnn" refers to a site not found in late texts. M. Naville shews it refers either to Heliopolis or Memphis, both of them very old cities; the god Sokaris was also sometimes called Hunnu, that may be because he possessed a temple there.

Before these memoranda upon the depositing of documents in ancient Egyptian sacred edifices are complete, reference must be made to a third instance of such a enstom which is to be found inscribed upon the temple at Dendera of as late a date as Ptolemy XIII. There is however ample reason to believe that most of the writings on this late sanctuary are careful copies from those upon an earlier building which the more splendid one replaced. As this extract is connected with the ancient ritual of the Hathor worship there, many copies among the temple archives must have been in possession of the hierarchy of the goddess, enabling them to supply the architectural sculptures with the correct version.

Upon the walls of one of the temple scripts which are covered with texts relating to religious festivals we read concerning one of these called "In the coming forth of this goddess a rds Edfou when she celebrates the "suval of the navigation" a great offering is made. All the prescribed ceremonies are performed to her during a four days' festival. The King of upper and lower Egypt, Thotmes, made his monuments to his mother, Hathor, lady of Denderah when he had found the great rule of Denderah in writings written upon the skin of a goat in the time of the followers of Horus. It was found inside a wall of bricks of the southern house of the time of the king of upper and lower Egypt Meri Ra-Pepi." .

The record is quite clear, it is a copy of a notice from Thothmes III that when he was renewing a wall of bricks, probably changing them for stone, as we know from other inscriptions of his he liked to do elsewhere, his workmen found old writings engrossed upon leather concealed in a brick wall erected by Meri Ra Pepi. For the document itself we know from an inscription in another part of the temple crypt dated from the time of Khofu. This text reading "This is the great rule (ie ritual of temple ceremonies) of Denders. The reconstruction of the buildings was made by the lord of diadema Thothmes .after it was found in old writings of the time of King Khufu."
The first memorandum explains that the text found written at the time of Khufu
"This extenet is much condensed for ways of space but the essential statements are given.

was a copy of the temple role dating from the end of the followers of Horus, that is before Menes. These Horus invaders M. Naville in his lectures two years ago at Paris, considers to have come from Asia by way of Arabia and the Sudan.

If in the greatly dilapidated remains of only a few of the many stately temples of Ancient Egypt we have already discovered records of three instances of old writings placed in the edifices for safe keeping there must have been many other similar cases.

The conclusion is inevitable that the religious and what may be termed masonic literature of old Egypt goes back for and away before the first dynasty inaugurated by Menes. This car ries back the age of some sort of civilization in Egypt many centuries. No surprise need now be felt at this for the discoveries in Babylonia and Elam are Similarly projecting into far-reaching antiquity the history of these countries, whilst the finding of numerous cave drawings and even paintings of animals long extinct in Europe in the valleys of southern France and northern Spain compels us to accept the residence of the human race endowed with artistic instincts for many thousands of years in We stern Europe.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The President of the Royal Drawing 80 the society, H.R.H. The Princess Louise, Duchess of Argyll, announces that King Edward has become Patron of the Society.

Captain Hugh R. Hendlam, who is the son of the Manchester Stipendiary Magistrate, has been granted the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidie (Fourth Clans) by the Sultan of Turkey for services rendered to the Khedive of Egypt. Captain Headlam, who completes ten years service in the York and Lancaster Regiment next month, has been attached to the Egyptian Army since 1908, and has been mentioned in despatches by the Sirdar.
It is announced that Lieut. Col. Sir John Harrington, who has been British Minister in Abyssinians for the past four years has become engaged to Miss Amy MoMillan, an American lady.

div.head: ROWING CLUBS REGATTA.
div.p: The finals of the regatta organised by the four rowing clubs of Alexandria, the Alex andria Rowing Club, Deutscher Sportverein, Club Nautique Français, and Club Internazionale Canottieri, which took place on the 28th alto., were rowed yesterday in the harbour. At 8.30 am. the skiff race was won by Mr. Seeger of the Deutscher Sportverein, and at half past five in the afternoon the four oared race was rowed and won by the Club Nautique Français. The emps offered by the four clubs were won by the following -
Club Nautique Français - Four-cared outrigger race Crew - Merr Porzinette (stroke), Verny, Greedy, Lorion, Barbaza (cox.)
Club Nautique Français :-Four on red yawl race. Crew :-Messrs. Gayot (stroke), Lemaitre, Ingott, Metager, Barbara (cox).
Alexandria Rowing Club : -Two oared yawl race. Crew Messrs. Chakour (stoke) Vasiliadi, Jules Chini (cox). Skiff Race Mr. Seeger.

The distribution of prizes took place last night at eight o'clock in the hall of the Club Nautique Français, and tents to the various clubs were drunk in copious draughts of champagne. A most enjoyable evening was spent and the party broke up in the best of spirits, highly delighted with the success of the afternoon's sport.

div.head: • STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The SS. "Highland Prince" lett London the 31st August; and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 16th inst.,

div.head: L'AFFAIRE COMMENTS
div.p: On sait que M. Coumes, propriétaire des journaux Cairotes "Vosporos" et "Bosphore", accusé de diffamation contre MM. Tambaco. poulos et Frangiscatos, a été condamné par le
Tribunal Consulaire de Grèce à 25 jours de e prison et aux frais. Nous extrayons d'un ar
ticle du "Bosphore" à ce sujet, signé Guémard,
les passages suivants : - Après cet arrêt contre un journal hellene
faisant suite à un verdier analogue contre trois familles indigènes, qu'il me soit permis de me demander avec mélancolie si la liberté de la presse n'est pas quelque peu méconnue en Egypte…

Mais quel a donc été le crime de Monsieur Jean Coumenos ? Il avait écrit que, d'une sous éruption publique, destinée à secourir les victims d'une catastrophe, des fonds avaient été détournés. Au moment de l'éruption de la Montagne Pelée, à la Martinique, des secours furent expédiés de même aux malheureux ministres. Or, plusieurs journaux français prétendaient qu'une bonne partie des sommes te cueillies avait fonda entre les mains du comité Ce fut un scandale épouvantable. Les journaux accusateurs eurent-ils à prouver leurs dies devant les tribunaux Pas le moins da monde. Bien qu'il y et diffamation caractérisée, ageun ne fut poursuivi. D'ailleurs même une condamnation n'serait pas modifié l'opinion publiqne.

Mais passons. Je ne réoriminerai pas contre la décision de l'augusto Arcopage d'Alexandrie, je pourrais, mois aussi, être traîné devant barre et jeté sans pitié dans une oubliette inconfortable ! Je me contenterai d'aviser noe lecteurs que dorénavant nous apprendrons à exprimer notre pénale d'une manière moins franche, à la voiler sons des réticences habiles À peser jusqu'à nos virgule et surtout a ne I pas confier trois lignes de notre écriture aux
typographes sans avoir consulté le Code Pénal Lou lieu du Larousse
